Problem:
Consider a function \( z(w) \) mapping complex numbers where \( z(w) \) is defined as \( z(w) = e^{i\omega w} \), with \( \omega \) being a real constant. We explore the implications of an integral transformation \( Z(v) \) on \( z(w) \), defined by \( Z(v) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} z(w) e^{-ivw} dw \).

Can we uniquely determine \( \omega \) from \( Z(v) \) without additional transformations?
Explanation: Given \( Z(v) \), which is a Fourier transform, results in \( 2\pi \delta(\omega - v) \). This clearly identifies \( \omega \) as the singular spike in the frequency domain identifies the dominant frequency component of \( z(w) \).
